abuse.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: cruel or violent treatment of someone
abuse.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: An independent committee will look into alleged human rights abuses.
Many children suffer racial abuse at school.
abuse.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: the use of something in a way that it should not be used
abuse.translation[0].definitions[1].note: alcohol/drug abuse (=the practice of drinking too much or taking illegal drugs)
abuse.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: A self-monitoring tax system is clearly open to abuse  (=able to be used wrongly).
abuse.translation[0].definitions[2].defi: rude or offensive things that someone says when they are angry
abuse.translation[0].definitions[2].note: a torrent/stream of abuse (=a series of rude or angry words)
abuse.translation[0].definitions[2].exam: vandalism and verbal abuse directed at old people
The other driver started hurling abuse at me.
abuse.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: to treat someone in a cruel and violent way, often sexually
abuse.translation[1].definitions[0].exam: She was sexually abused as a child.
abuse.translation[1].definitions[1].defi: to deliberately use something for the wrong purpose or for your own advantage
abuse.translation[1].definitions[1].exam: Williams abused his position as mayor to give jobs to his friends.
Morris abused the trust the firm had shown in him.
The proportion of drinkers who abuse alcohol is actually quite small.
abuse.translation[1].definitions[2].defi: to say rude or offensive things to someone
abuse.translation[1].definitions[2].exam: Many soldiers in Belfast are verbally abused.
He came to the help of another driver who was being racially abused by three white passengers.
abuse.translation[1].definitions[3].defi: to treat something so badly that you start to destroy it
abuse.translation[1].definitions[3].exam: James abused his body for years with heroin and cocaine.
